Decimation (Latin: decimatio; decem = "ten") was a form of military discipline 
used by senior commanders in the Roman Army to punish units or large groups 
guilty of capital offences, such as mutiny or desertion. The word decimation is 
derived from Latin meaning "removal of a tenth". ... Because the punishment fell
